prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The story is about a husband setting up his home office in the bedroom, which causes the wife a lot of inconvenience. The wife suggested the basement, which has better space, but he prefers the bedroom for the view. His job involves a lot of conference calls, so the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him, which limits her ability to do her own work, chores, and even basic things like showering. She works from home too and handles most of the housework and kids. The husband is upset she can't keep silent in the bedroom, while she's upset he didn't use the basement.

First, I need to determine if the author (the wife) is in the wrong. The key points here are about boundaries and mutual respect. The husband chose a space that's shared (the bedroom) over a dedicated space (the basement), which is logical because the basement would minimize disruptions. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a situation where his work encroaches on the wife's personal space and responsibilities. The wife is trying to maintain her own work-life balance and household duties but can't because the office is in their private area. 

Is the wife wrong for not keeping him undisturbed? Well, the husband made a choice that affects her negatively. While it's reasonable to expect some quiet during calls, it's also unreasonable to expect the entire house to be silent when there are kids and chores. The husband should have considered the practical implications of setting up in the bedroom. The wife is not at fault for pointing out the impracticality and the impact on her own life. The husband's preference for the view shouldn't override the practicality and the wife's needs. So the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong.
